attributes.title: Social isolation and vocabulary development: insights from families with varying SES (Polish)
attributes.description: Family socioeconomic status (SES) can indirectly influence child language development, as it is linked to the quantity and quality of speech heard by children (Hoff, 2003; Rowe, 2012). Discrepancies between low- and high-SES families in the quantity of language input may be as high as 30 million word tokens heard by a child over the first three years of life (Hart & Risley, 1995). Such diminished quantity of speech heard by children directly impedes their early language development (Hart & Risley, 1995) and has lasting consequences for their subsequent school outcomes (Hart & Risley, 2003). However, since many Polish toddlers spend most of their waking time outside of home, in kindergartens or day cares, it is difficult to extract the influence of family SES on their development. Such opportunity came with the spread of coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and the general lockdown in Poland, which forced all the children to stay at home with the parents. In the present study we investigate home activities and parental interactions with 8-36 month-old infants and toddlers in families with various SES background. We compare children’s early vocabulary knowledge at the beginning of lockdown and after the kindergartens are re-opened. The present study is part of a larger international project “Social isolation and vocabulary development: insights from families with varying SES” (https://osf.io/3ayc6/).

q1.value: Magdalena Łuniewska, Agnieszka Kacprzak, Karolina Mieszkowska

q2.value:
In accordance with the original research plan, we postulate the following hypotheses:
(1) We expect that during the lockdown, parents from lower SES backgrounds will engage in shared book reading activities and structured parent-infant interactions less than parents from higher SES backgrounds.
(2) We expect that during the lockdown, infants in lower SES families might be exposed to TV/cartoons more than infants in higher SES families.
(3) We expect that after the lockdown is revoked, infants growing up in lower SES families will have smaller gains in both receptive and expressive vocabulary compared to infants in higher SES families.
(4) We expect that the time spent daily on shared book reading will explain more variance in vocabulary size than the time spent daily on other child-parent activities (see Montag et al., 2015).
(5) We predict that more use of dialogue style in shared book reading will be related to larger gains in expressive vocabulary (Flack et al., 2015).
(6) We expect that more exposure to TV/baby cartoons will be related to smaller gains in receptive vocabulary (cf Kuhl et al., 2003).

Additionally, taking into account the characteristics of the Polish sample, we further hypothesize that:
(7) The gain in the vocabulary will be larger in children who had attended preschools / kindergartens before lockdown than in children who had stayed at homes with their parents.
(8) The gain in the vocabulary will be larger in children whose parents stopped working during the lockdown than in children whose parents were working remotely.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study has a regression design: we will examine whether family's SES, time spent on shared book reading, structured plays and TV/baby cartoons exposure modulate gains in receptive and expressive vocabulary sizes.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will contact, via social media, Polish parents of infants and toddlers from 8 to 36 months of age and will invite them to take part in the current longitudinal study. The study will be carried online. The participants will fill out an online questionnaire at Time 1 (T1, at the beginning of /during the lockdown period) and a similar one at Time 2 (T2, after the lockdown is revoked). The questionnaires will be hosted on QUALTRICS. Both questionnaires include a language questionnaire (Polish adaptation of MB-CDI-I, Smoczyńska et al., 2015) and a family background questionnaire (that includes information about siblings' gender and age and family's SES). Additionally, at Time 2, the parents will be asked what type of activities they engaged in with their child (and the time spent daily on each type) during the lockdown period. The language questionnaires will provide us with an estimate of a child's vocabulary size at Time 1 and Time 2. The following child exclusion criteria will be used: preterm birth (before the end of 37th week of pregnancy); present or recovered auditory or visual deficits.

q11.value: We will stop the recruitment as soon as coronavirus lockdown is revoked in Poland. Till then we aim to invite as many participants as possible, knowing that a response rate for online longitudinal studies is around 10%-15%. The families that join the study for less than a week before the end of the lockdown won’t be included in the analyses.

q13.value: We will stop the recruitment as soon as coronavirus lockdown is revoked in Poland.

question.value:
We will use the variables structured by the authors of the original study plan:
Our dependent variable is the total number of words that parents will report their child
understands (between 8 and 18 months of age) and produces (between 8 and 36 months of age). The total number of words transformed to the percentile score (adjusted for age and gender) will be used as the dependent variable in the analyses.
Our predictors are: the time spent daily on shared book reading during the lockdown period; the time spent daily on structured child-parent interactions, the amount of exposure to TV/cartoons.
Maternal education (varying from 0 - elementary school to 6 - PhD) will be used as a proxy of SES and will be included as a predictor in the analyses.
We will also count the number of days between T1 and T2 (Gap_days) and will include it as a covariate in the analyses.

We will follow the Analysis Plan structured by the authors of the original study plan (https://osf.io/3ayc6/):
First, we will examine the number of participants and the distribution of the SES backgrounds across the 7 possible categories (coded as a continuous variable, varying from 0 - elementary school to 6 - PhD). If the distribution is not homogeneous and we have relatively few answers per category (less than 5), then we will recode the SES variable into a binary factor (low [from 0 to 3], and high [from 4 to 6]).
Then, we will examine the role of different activities parents have engaged in during the quarantine period and the gain score in the vocabulary size. Modality (receptive vs expressive) will be included as a factor for 8-18-month-old infants and will be included as a random variable. We will also model a possible interaction between the time spent daily on reading and Modality (cf Karras et al, 2005).
We will also include Gap_days as a covariate in the analyses, as we expect larger gains of more days have passed between Time 1 and Time 2. Gains~Time_spent_read+Time_spent_interaction+Time_spent_TV+Time_spent_outdoor+Maternal_educ+ Modality + Modality:Time_Spent_read+Gap_days+(1|Child), data=8_18_mo_data
If the model does not converge, then the interaction term will be removed from the model and the analyses will be performed for each modality separately.
Second, we will perform similar analyses for the expressive vocabulary (modality will be removed).
For this, we will merge data on expressive vocabulary from 8-18 and 19-36-months of age.
Gains~Time_spent_read+Time_spent_interaction+Time_spent_TV+Time_spent_outdoor+Maternal_educ+ Gap_days, data=8_36_mo_data
For those infants whose parents do engage in shared book reading, we will examine the role of type of reading and frequency of reading in each data sample.
Gains~Type_reading+Time_spent_read+Maternal_educ+Gap_days
In a separate series of analyses, we will examine differences in everyday activities across families from different SES backgrounds. If the data permits (see above), then correlation analyses will be performed between Maternal_educ (7 categories, coded as a continuous variable) and the time spent on of different activities during the lockdown period; if not, then a binary factor of SES will be used and then all the data will be split in two (families with high and families with low SES).

q18.value:
We will follow the transformation plans set out by the authors of the original study plan:
For each child, the vocabulary size in percentile at Time 1 will be subtracted from the vocabulary size at Time 2 (in percentile), separately for receptive and expressive modality. As a result, we will obtain two gain scores (one for receptive and one for expressive vocabulary) for 8 to 18 month-old infants and one gain score for 19 to 36-month-old infants. The gain scores will be used in the statistical analyses.

q20.value: We will exclude observations with incomplete questionnaires.

q21.value: We will exclude observations with incomplete questionnaires.

q22.value:
We will examine whether there are differences between those infants who already
attended a kindergarten before the coronavirus outbreak and those who did not. Additionally, we will explore whether the fact that child’s parents have been working remotely during the lockdown period has an impact on vocabulary learning.

attributes.title: Erik Dockins FInal Project
attributes.description: Previous research has displayed that the gendered elements included in advertisements can affect an individual's willingness to purchase a product. This study aims to test the impacts that the gendered context a product is set in can have on an individual's willingness to view the product as desirable

q1.value: Christen Dockins, Maura Flynn, Robert Gentilucci, Amanda Monetti, Madison Pristera, Caitlyn Pritchard, Ashley Santos, Raymond Zuhowski, Samantha Zupko, Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen, Minka Bolognese, Ella Campbell, Patricia Carballo, Sheahan Collins, Madeline Eickman, Ryenn Hayes, Amanda Herzig, Tess Hodder, Gabriel Legido, Ann McConnon, Michael McDermott, Alyssa McDougall, Kara McSweeney, Corinne O'Neill, Claire Pier, Allison Quinter, Carley Rose, Lauren Rossi, Gabriella Senni, Brendan Steigerwald, Nolan Vagnozzi, Alexa Weber

q2.value: Men will respond more positively to products that are advertised in a masculine context, and women will respond more positively to products that are advertised in a feminine context. Additionally, I predict that advertisements with feminine context will be rated as more desirable overall.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2(gender of subject) x 2(gender of imagery and context)

question.value: I am posting a link to my survey on both Twitter and Facebook. The survey consists of two sections, the first being demographics, and the second section details two hypothetical advertisements for an alcoholic beverage. Subjects will read both advertisements and then rank how desirable they find the product on a scale of 1-10, with 10 being the highest.

ANOVA to test for interactions between participant gender and gendered imagery

attributes.title: Does group self-affirmation reduce high-identifiers’ resistance to alcohol norm information?

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Does group self-affirmation reduce high-identifiers’ resistance to alcohol norm information?

sample.value:
The primary determinant of sample size will be resources in terms of time and available incentives. Given the need to complete data collection in February 2020 while also obtaining a sample size sufficient to find small-medium effects given the design, our aim is to recruit 400 participants in the first part of the study, and retain as many of these as possible.

In terms of statistical power, a sensitivity analysis in G*power 3.1 indicated that a sample of 400 provides 80% power to detect an effect as small as p2 =.019 (f = 0.140) given the design (largest dfnum = 1). Assuming a 75% retention rate for the follow-up, a sample of 300 provides 80% power to detect an effect as small as p2 =.026 (f = 0.162).

analyses.value:
The main hypothesis will be tested using a 2(drinking norm information: low vs. control) X 2 (group affirmation: social life vs. ethical) X ingroup identification (continuous, standardized) X typical consumption (continuous, standardized) ANOVA on intended alcohol consumption, and on actual consumption assessed to follow-up. We also intend to conduct similar ANOVAs on both outcomes with attitude replacing typical consumption as a moderator; that is, a 2(drinking norm information: low vs. control) X 2 (group affirmation: social life vs. ethical) X ingroup identification (continuous, standardized) X attitude (continuous, standardized) ANOVA.

Simple main effects analyses will also be conducted to test the effect of the norm information manipulation at the specific combination of the moderators identified in section 1 (high identification; high typical consumption; self-affirmation control and group self-affirmation conditions).

Secondary analyses will involve running similar ANOVAs on the perceived importance of alcohol to ingroup identity, and on the perceived importance of ethical behaviour to ingroup identity. These analyses test whether the self-affirmation moderation effects described above also affect the subjective importance of the behaviour in question to ingroup identity.

outliers.value: Inclusion criteria are that participants must be undergraduate students at the ingroup University. Participants’ data will be excluded after data collection if they have > 40% missing values, or do not meet the inclusion criteria.

dependent.value:
Pre-manipulation measures
 
Ingroup identification. Section one consists of a six-item scale of ingroup identification based on the scales used by Doosje, Ellemers, and Spears (1995) and Livingstone et al. (2011), including statements such as “I identify with other University of ___ students’. Responses are made on a 7-point scale (-3= strongly disagree, 3 = strongly agree). 
 
Attitudes towards heavy alcohol consumption. A diagram summarising the number of alcohol units in a range of popular drinks based on UK government standards (National Health Service, 2018) is presented before the seven-item scale of personal attitude toward heavy alcohol consumption, based on the scale used by Livingstone et al. (2011). The seven-item semantic differential scale measures attitudes towards drinking 14 units of alcohol over the next 7 days. The scales are anchored with word-pairs such as ‘unenjoyable-enjoyable’. A positive number on this scale would indicate a more favourable attitude towards heavy alcohol consumption.

Typical weekly alcohol consumption. Participants’ typical weekly alcohol consumption will be assessed by asking participants to enter how many units of alcohol they consume in a typical week (7 days). The response format is open-ended, and participants will enter a value.

Post-manipulation measures

Group affirmation manipulation check. As a manipulation check, participants will be required to report their opinion on how ethical/moral ingroup behaviour is. This will be done on 4 items using a 7-point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale. 

 
Norm information manipulation check. An open-ended manipulation check will ask participants to indicate ‘the mean units of alcohol consumed on an average evening of drinking by University of ___ students. Participants in the control condition will not be presented with this graph or information and will only be required to answer the manipulation check item.
 
Alcohol consumption intentions. Alcohol consumption intentions will be assessed in two ways. First, participants will be asked to enter how many units of alcohol they intend to consume over the next week (7 days). The response format is open-ended, and participants will enter a value. Second, a 2-item scale will assess intentions to consume 14 units of alcohol over the 7-days post-completion. Participants will be asked whether they agree or disagree with two statements and responses will be assessed using a 7 point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale. 

Perceived importance of alcohol consumption to ingroup identity. This will be assessed on a 4-item scale including items such as ‘Consuming alcohol is an important part of being a University of ___ student.’ Responses will be assessed using a 7 point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale.

Perceived importance of ethical behaviour to ingroup identity. A similar 4-item scale will assess the perceived importance of ethical behaviour to ingroup identity (e.g., ‘Being ethical is an important part of being a University of ___ student.’)


Follow up questionnaire (administered seven days later)

Alcohol consumption behaviour. The follow up study (sent one week after the first part) will require participants to self-report their alcohol consumption behaviour over the preceding seven days. Participants will be asked to enter how many units they consumed on each of those days, using an open-ended format in each case. These values will be summed to create an overall score for consumption in the previous week.

Additional questions. Do you think this was a typical week for you? 
Yes/No; 
If you answered no to the previous question, did you consume more or less units than you would in a typical week?
Yes/No

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. The study has a 2 (alcohol/drinking norm: low vs control ) X 2(group self-affirmation: ethical identity vs control) between-participants design. The control conditions involve giving no additional information to participants.

hypothesis.value:
The study examines whether a group self-affirmation manipulation could mitigate the tendency for high identifiers to backlash against alcohol norm information that suggests low alcohol consumption is the ingroup norm. Self-affirmation theory suggests that one way to reduce resistance to information that threatens a valued aspect of the self is to affirm an alternative aspect of the self (Sherman & Cohen, 2002, 2006). When the self has been affirmed in this manner, people have been found to be more receptive to challenging information (Sherman et al., 2000), and to more readily adapt their beliefs and behaviour. Group self-affirmation refers to this process as it occurs for social identities (Badea, Binning, Verlhiac, & Sherman, 2018; Ehrlich & Gramzow, 2015; Sherman, Kinias, Major, Kim, & Prenovost, 2007): group members should be less resistant to information that challenges a valued aspect of ingroup identity when their social identity has been affirmed (an idea similar to social creativity as an identity management strategy; Tajfel & Turner, 1979). While the relevance of self-affirmation to alcohol interventions has been established (see Ehret, LaBrie, Santerre, & Sherman, 2015, for a review), the evidence thus far has focused on individual-level identities. This leaves open the question of whether group self-affirmation can reduce resistance to group-focused alcohol interventions such as social marketing approaches that seek to correct descriptive group norms about alcohol consumption.

To test this, the study will have a 2 X 2 between-participants design in which ingroup alcohol norm information (low or control) and group self affirmation (affirmed/ethical identity vs control) are orthogonally manipulated. The main questionnaire will measure their reported typical and intended alcohol consumption. In a follow-up questionnaire administered seven days later, we will measure through self report their actual alcohol consumption behaviour in the seven days since the main part of the study. In line with previous studies that have tested the social identity model of resistance to norm information, we also included participants’ ingroup identification, individual-level attitude to heavy alcohol consumption, and typical weekly alcohol consumption in the model tested in each study.

In terms of hypotheses, we expect that the effect of norm information on intended and actual consumption will depend on the group affirmation manipulation, ingroup identification, and typical alcohol consumption/attitude towards alcohol consumption.
Specifically, when ingroup identification is high and typical consumption is high, the effect of the norm information manipulation will be different depending on the self-affirmation condition. In the control self-affirmation condition, we expect to see resistance to the norm information in terms of no, or even a reversed effect of the norm information (i.e., higher intentions and consumption reported in the low norm condition compared to the control). In contrast, we expect intentions and consumption to align more with the norm information in the group self-affirmation condition (i.e., lower intentions and consumption in the low norm condition compared to the control condition). We also intend to test this hypothesis in an alternative model with attitude towards alcohol substituted in for typical consumption, with a similar predicted pattern.

A diagram summarising the number of alcohol units in a range of popular drinks based on UK government standards (National Health Service, 2018) is presented before the seven-item scale of personal attitude toward heavy alcohol consumption, based on the scale used by Livingstone et al. (2011). The seven-item semantic differential scale measures attitudes towards drinking 14 units of alcohol over the next 7 days. The scales are anchored with word-pairs such as ‘unenjoyable-enjoyable’. A positive number on this scale would indicate a more favourable attitude towards heavy alcohol consumption.

Typical weekly alcohol consumption. Participants’ typical weekly alcohol consumption will be assessed by asking participants to enter how many units of alcohol they consume in a typical week (7 days). The response format is open-ended, and participants will enter a value.

Post-manipulation measures

Group affirmation manipulation check. As a manipulation check, participants will be required to report their opinion on how ethical/moral ingroup behaviour is. This will be done on 4 items using a 7-point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale. 

 
Norm information manipulation check. An open-ended manipulation check will ask participants to indicate ‘the mean units of alcohol consumed on an average evening of drinking by University of ___ students. Participants in the control condition will not be presented with this graph or information and will only be required to answer the manipulation check item.
 
Alcohol consumption intentions. Alcohol consumption intentions will be assessed in two ways. First, participants will be asked to enter how many units of alcohol they intend to consume over the next week (7 days). The response format is open-ended, and participants will enter a value. Second, a 2-item scale will assess intentions to consume 14 units of alcohol over the 7-days post-completion. Participants will be asked whether they agree or disagree with two statements and responses will be assessed using a 7 point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale. 

Perceived importance of alcohol consumption to ingroup identity. This will be assessed on a 4-item scale including items such as ‘Consuming alcohol is an important part of being a University of ___ student.’ Responses will be assessed using a 7 point (-3 = strongly disagree; 3 = strongly agree) scale.

Perceived importance of ethical behaviour to ingroup identity. A similar 4-item scale will assess the perceived importance of ethical behaviour to ingroup identity (e.g., ‘Being ethical is an important part of being a University of ___ student.’)


Follow up questionnaire (administered seven days later)

Alcohol consumption behaviour. The follow up study (sent one week after the first part) will require participants to self-report their alcohol consumption behaviour over the preceding seven days. Participants will be asked to enter how many units they consumed on each of those days, using an open-ended format in each case. These values will be summed to create an overall score for consumption in the previous week.

Additional questions. Do you think this was a typical week for you? 
Yes/No; 
If you answered no to the previous question, did you consume more or less units than you would in a typical week?
Yes/No
registration_responses.conditions: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the four conditions. The study has a 2 (alcohol/drinking norm: low vs control ) X 2(group self-affirmation: ethical identity vs control) between-participants design. The control conditions involve giving no additional information to participants.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The study examines whether a group self-affirmation manipulation could mitigate the tendency for high identifiers to backlash against alcohol norm information that suggests low alcohol consumption is the ingroup norm. Self-affirmation theory suggests that one way to reduce resistance to information that threatens a valued aspect of the self is to affirm an alternative aspect of the self (Sherman & Cohen, 2002, 2006). When the self has been affirmed in this manner, people have been found to be more receptive to challenging information (Sherman et al., 2000), and to more readily adapt their beliefs and behaviour. Group self-affirmation refers to this process as it occurs for social identities (Badea, Binning, Verlhiac, & Sherman, 2018; Ehrlich & Gramzow, 2015; Sherman, Kinias, Major, Kim, & Prenovost, 2007): group members should be less resistant to information that challenges a valued aspect of ingroup identity when their social identity has been affirmed (an idea similar to social creativity as an identity management strategy; Tajfel & Turner, 1979). While the relevance of self-affirmation to alcohol interventions has been established (see Ehret, LaBrie, Santerre, & Sherman, 2015, for a review), the evidence thus far has focused on individual-level identities. This leaves open the question of whether group self-affirmation can reduce resistance to group-focused alcohol interventions such as social marketing approaches that seek to correct descriptive group norms about alcohol consumption.

To test this, the study will have a 2 X 2 between-participants design in which ingroup alcohol norm information (low or control) and group self affirmation (affirmed/ethical identity vs control) are orthogonally manipulated. The main questionnaire will measure their reported typical and intended alcohol consumption. In a follow-up questionnaire administered seven days later, we will measure through self report their actual alcohol consumption behaviour in the seven days since the main part of the study. In line with previous studies that have tested the social identity model of resistance to norm information, we also included participants’ ingroup identification, individual-level attitude to heavy alcohol consumption, and typical weekly alcohol consumption in the model tested in each study.

In terms of hypotheses, we expect that the effect of norm information on intended and actual consumption will depend on the group affirmation manipulation, ingroup identification, and typical alcohol consumption/attitude towards alcohol consumption.
Specifically, when ingroup identification is high and typical consumption is high, the effect of the norm information manipulation will be different depending on the self-affirmation condition. In the control self-affirmation condition, we expect to see resistance to the norm information in terms of no, or even a reversed effect of the norm information (i.e., higher intentions and consumption reported in the low norm condition compared to the control). In contrast, we expect intentions and consumption to align more with the norm information in the group self-affirmation condition (i.e., lower intentions and consumption in the low norm condition compared to the control condition). We also intend to test this hypothesis in an alternative model with attitude towards alcohol substituted in for typical consumption, with a similar predicted pattern.

attributes.title: RESEARCH USING POPULATION-BASED ADMINISTRATION DATA LINKED TO LONGITUDINAL SURVEYS IN OUT-OF-HOME CARE OR CHILD PROTECTION SETTINGS: A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW
attributes.description: Synthesis and reporting of studies using population-based administrative data linked to longitudinal surveys in child protection or out-of-home care settings

q1.value: RESEARCH USING POPULATION-BASED ADMINISTRATION DATA LINKED TO LONGITUDINAL SURVEYS IN OUT-OF-HOME CARE OR CHILD PROTECTION SETTINGS: A SYSTEMATIC REVIEW

q3.value:
The primary objectives of the systematic review are:
1.	To synthesize and describe the different research designs reported when integrating administrative data to longitudinal surveys in out-of-home care or child protection settings
2.	To describe and assess the statistical methods used when retrospective administrative data is linked to prospective longitudinal surveys. 
We will discuss the suitability of the methods identified in the included studies. The aim is not to document methods of the data linkage process, but rather provide evidence on the different ways in which linked data can be used to enhance survey data thereby minimising risk of bias and other limitations reported. 

The findings from this review will enhance our understanding, applications and enhanced use of data from linking multiple administrative databases and self-ported survey measures to understand various measures and associations in multiple domains. This systematic review is an essential step towards informing policy, practice and future research directions in methodological aspects of using linked data and survey data.

q4.value:
The non-directional hypothesis we would like to test is as follows:
There is insufficient evidence regarding use of administrative data linked to longitudinal surveys to report on outcomes involving out-of-home care or child protection settings.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A synthesis of peer reviewed journal articles reporting on administrative data linked to longitudinal surveys in child protection or out-of-home care settings. A systematic search of articles has been conducted from online databases and other data sources including reference list scrutiny.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Information Sources:

Research articles were searched from Medline (Ovid), Embase, ERIC, CINAHL and Pscyinfo databases. In addition, a search was conducted on some websites which provide a publication repository where data linkage units may list peer-reviewed publications, such as the Population Health Research Network (PHRN). The reference list of included studies was manually scrutinised to find any relevant studies. This provided an invaluable source of articles for inclusion. Searches were conducted using free-text in all databases. 

Search Strategy

In line with the objectives of this review, three strings were used to search for articles in the relevant journals, and these include the following:
1.	Data Source
2.	Longitudinal Survey/ Study 
3.	“Out-of home care” or “child protection”

A full search strategy is attached.

q13.value: The systematic review yielded a total of 739 articles after duplicates were removed. Out of these a total of 32 articles met the inclusion criteria and the 32 articles will undergo quality appraisal and synthesis of the main findings.

q15.value: The search for the articles only stops when all possible sources of data are exhausted. In this review, all key online databases were searched, including searching on google scholar, data linkage websites, major child health, child maltreatment or child abuse longitudinal studies' websites. This ensured a comprehensive set of articles were retrieved including manually scrutinizing reference lists of included studies.

question.value:
Data extracted will include the following broad summary measures: study/ population characteristics, population/ sample size, measurement scales, data collection tools, validation methods and analysis method.  Specific variables that will be extracted include the following:

Study/ Population characteristics: Citation, year of publication, aims/ objectives, research area, study location, out-of-home care or child protection setting 
Administrative Data: Source & name of administrative data, Sample/ population size of data, number of administrative datasets, linkage type and linkage quality
Longitudinal Survey data: Name of study, study duration, sampling method, study population (Age at baseline, gender, cohort size at baseline. Number of waves reported and sample sizes for each, attrition rate, standardised and non-standardised outcome measures, timeframe between waves, biases reported, and sensitivity analysis
Statistical Methods: Domain of statistical analysis, analysis procedure, statistical parameters of reporting, tests for assumptions, confounding variables, mediating/ moderating variables, outcome variables, independent variables.
No specific variables will be measured since this study is a narrative/ qualitative synthesis.
All variables defined in the data abstraction section will be manipulated without specifying outcome or confound variables since this review is focused on methodology.
The analysis will be descriptive and narrative synthesis from the sample of 32 included studies. No meta analysis will be conducted in this study since the articles will be heterogeneous in nature.

q22.value: Articles which have a methodological quality rating below 50% will be excluded from the analysis and synthesis of results.

attributes.title: Mother-infant autonomic physiological and observed affective synchrony during the Still-Face Procedure
attributes.description: The purpose of this study is to examine patterns of mother-infant autonomic (heart rate, RSA) and observed affective (positive, neutral, negative emotional facial expressions) synchrony over the course of the Still-Face Procedure (SFP; Tronick et al., 1978). We will also examine the role of mothers’ attachment representations and symptoms of psychopathology in predicting mother-infant synchrony during the SFP. Finally, we will examine the significance of mother-infant synchrony during the SFP for infant socioemotional adjustment, as indexed by social competence and behavioral problems.

attributes.title: Neuroticism and Interpretive Bias as Risk Factors for Anxiety and Depression
attributes.description:
Neuroticism has been associated with mood and anxiety pathology both cross-sectionally and longitudinally. Interpretive bias, or the tendency to interpret ambiguous stimuli in a positive or negative manner, has been associated with mood and anxiety symptomatology, primarily in cross-sectional and bias induction studies. The purpose of the current study was to first examine the role of interpretive bias as a prospective risk factor and second as a possible mediator of the relation between neuroticism and depression and anxiety in a sample of young adults assessed longitudinally.

NOTE: Please reach out to the principal investigators of the Youth Emotion Project (Richard Zinbarg, Michelle Craske, Susan Mineka) before using data for any purpose aside from re-running our analyses.

summary.value: The registration contains data and results from our investigation of neuroticism and interpretive bias as risk factors for anxiety and depression.  These materials will help interested researchers understand the analyses we conducted.

registration_responses.summary: The registration contains data and results from our investigation of neuroticism and interpretive bias as risk factors for anxiety and depression.  These materials will help interested researchers understand the analyses we conducted.

attributes.title: A Social Ecological Approach to Adolescent Mental Health in the Digital Age - An ABCD Study Analysis
attributes.description:
Adolescence is a dynamic time in development which is associated with enhanced opportunities and vulnerabilities due to vast physical, psychological, and social changes. A rising prevalence of depression and anxiety among adolescents in the U.S., with approximately 22% with severe impairments (Bose, 2017; NIMH, 2019), has evoked growing concerns around causes for this rise, especially considering the digital age. Adolescents are the largest adopters of technology, with approximately 95% having access to a mobile device, 71% using one or more social media platforms, and 45% claiming to be online “almost constantly” (Pew Research Center, 2018). While many studies have shown associations between screen time and poor mental health outcomes (Kırcaburun et al., 2018; Lemola et al., 2015; McBride, 2017; Sampasa-Kanyinga & Lewis, 2015; Stiglic & Viner, 2019; Twenge & Campbell, 2018; Twenge et al., 2018), recent reviews of the literature show mixed and inconsistencies in these findings (Best et al., 2014; Odgers, 2018; Rideout, 2018; Sarmiento et al., 2018; Wartella et al., 2016). 

A recent rigorous analysis of large-scale datasets by Orben and Przybylski (2019) revealed associations between screen time and wellbeing in adolescents suggesting small effects sizes which can be comparable to many other possible and unrelated correlates to mental health outcomes in adolescents. This posits a greater consideration that must be made in statistical inferences in efforts to address the complex nature in the rise of internalizing behaviors such as depressive and anxiety symptoms in youth. 

Many established lines of research investigating predictors, beyond individual factors such as screen time (Odgers, 2018) and cognitive functioning (Shortt & Spence, 2006), to poor mental health outcomes in adolescents include family (Sander & McCarty, 2005) and peer factors (Garland & Fitzgerald, 1998; MacPhee & Andrews, 2006), school functioning (Juvonen et al., 2000; Fröjd et al., 2008), neighborhood (Aneshensel & Sucoff, 1996) and community factors (Huynh & Fuligni, 2010). This multi-level perspective echoes the social ecological framework (Bronfenbrenner & Morris, 2006; Stokols, 2018), which recognizes the interplay of the various ecologies, proximal and distal to the individual, on mental health during this developmental period. The objective of this study is to investigate the social ecological factors associated with adolescent mental health in the digital age. Using a multimodal baseline dataset from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) study (Volkow et al., 2017), we will be able to characterize correlates to mental health outcomes of a diverse U.S. adolescent cohort, inclusive of the various ecological factors. The aims of this study are threefold: (1) to evaluate the associations between screen time and internalizing behaviors, (2) to evaluate the associations between multi-level ecological factors previously identified as risk factors for increases in internalizing behaviors among adolescents, and (3) explore differences in these associations stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups.

q2.value:
Aim 1: Evaluate the relation between screen time and internalizing behaviors in early adolescence. 

H1a: Greater screen time in early adolescence will have small positive association to increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H1b: The positive association between screen time and internalizing behaviors will be stronger (moderated) among females. 

Aim 2: Evaluate social ecological factors previously known to be associated with poor mental health outcomes/internalizing behaviors

H2a: Poor family dynamics will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2b: Poor peer relationships will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2c: Poor school functioning will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2d: Lower levels of neighborhood safety will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2e: Heightened levels of perceived access to drugs and alcohol will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 


Aim 3 (Exploratory): Explore unique SES and racial/ethnic group differences on the associations between multi-level ecological factors and poor mental health outcomes in adolescents.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This study draws from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, which has been designed as an open-access dataset through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The ABCD study is designed to be a multimodal longitudinal study uniquely capturing the development of adolescences through neuroimaging, biospecimen, neurocognition, mental and physical health measures, and equivalent parental self-reported measures across 10 years and 21 sites in the United States. Details of the adolescent sampling for recruitment can be found in prior publication (Garavan et al., 2018). 

For this particular analysis, I will be utilizing the self-reported measures of demographic information, psychological wellbeing, cognitive functioning, screen time, family dynamics, school functioning, neighborhood safety and community environment.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value:
The proposed data analysis will approach the currently available Baseline cross-sectional data (2.0.1) of this 10-year longitudinal dataset with a more holistic approach to understanding correlates and trends of development and wellbeing across a diverse group of US adolescents. This in efforts to promote research with an open-science framework. To ensure the blinding of patterns and summary statistics of variable of interest beyond demographic information, we will be utilizing the Data Exploration Analysis Portal (DEAP) which has taken measures to prevent post hoc hypothesis testing. Exploratory analysis will be conducted to investigate differences in mental health outcomes stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups. 

To my knowledge there have not been studies published yet looking at direct relations between screen time and internalizing behaviors using this dataset, alongside the interplay of multi-level ecological variables related to mental health outcomes in adolescence.

question.value: Recruitment for this study is across 21 catchment areas in the mainland United States and data from children and parents are stored in the main data management site of University of California, San Diego. As a part of the open-access data initiative, the NIH has made the deidentified data publicly available for researchers globally. The data was obtained through data user agreement between NIH and UCI and an exempt data analysis protocol is in place for this specific study analysis, as there will be no direct interaction with the study participants and only data will be analyzed.

q11.value: The sample size for the baseline data of this adolescent cohort is 11,880. Parent/caregiver data is also collected, thus the sample size of adults in this study are 11,880 individuals at baseline data collection. This number is expected to decrease when accounting for missing data, which will be analyzed after pre-registration.

q12.value: This sample size was over sampled with the anticipated attrition rates (10%) in a 10-year longitudinal study of this magnitude. To capture the national diversity of the adolescent population in the U.S., a multi-stage probability sampling design of schools around each study site was conducted. There was an oversampling of African American and other races and relative under-sampling of Caucasian and Hispanics in order to achieve a more optimal racial/ethnic distribution in this cohort of adolescents (Garavan et al., 2018).

question.value: N/A

Outcome(s): Internalizing Behaviors (CBCL)

Predictors/Correlates: Screen Time; Cognitive Functioning (NIH Toolbox) Parental Monitoring Survey; Youth Family Environment Scale; Resiliency Survey (Peer Relationships); School Risk and Protective Factors; Brief Problem Monitoring; Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey; Community Drug Availability Measure

Covariates: Youth Demographics (age, gender, race/ethnicity); Parent Demographics (SES, highest education level, marital status)

(Please see attached document for details on each measure: JMHthesis_PreReg_VariableTable_UPDATE200410.docx)
N/A

Descriptive and frequency statistics will be initially conducted to understand the demographic and internalizing behavior (e.g. depressive and anxiety symptom) distributions of this study cohort. 

Bivariate correlations will be conducted to characterize the associations between multi-level ecological factors and internalizing behaviors. Effect sizes will be reported to compare the magnitude of the associations of potential predictors of internalizing behaviors. Multiple linear regression analysis will be performed to further investigate the associations between the ecological factors and internalizing behaviors above and beyond covariate demographic factors and relative to the factors of each ecological level to identify unique predictive factors of screen time. 

**Please see attached variable document for measure information
Outcome variables: internalizing behaviors (CBCL, KSADS) 
Predictor variables: Individual factors (Screen Time, Cognitive Functioning), family dynamics (Family Environment Survey, Parental monitoring Survey), peer relationships (Resilience Survey), school functioning (Brief Problem Monitoring – Teacher reported), neighborhood environment (Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey), and community environment (Discrimination Survey). 
Covariates: child demographics (age, sex given at birth, race/ethnicity, pubertal development); parent demographics (family SES, highest parent education, marital status)

As an exploratory aim, run descriptives and bivariate correlations will be conducted stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. We will conduct similar multiple regression models stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups, then test potential interaction effects.

q22.value: We expect there may be differences in effect sizes across group of race/ethnicity and familial socioeconomic status. Therefore, as the exploratory aim, we will stratify by groups of race/ethnicity and familial SES and conduct bivariate correlates and multiple regression analyses to better understand potential unique associations between the multi-level ecological predictors and internalizing behavior outcomes.

Analysis had not been run prior to selecting an appropriate community-level measure.

registration_responses.q2:
Aim 1: Evaluate the relation between screen time and internalizing behaviors in early adolescence. 

H1a: Greater screen time in early adolescence will have small positive association to increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H1b: The positive association between screen time and internalizing behaviors will be stronger (moderated) among females. 

Aim 2: Evaluate social ecological factors previously known to be associated with poor mental health outcomes/internalizing behaviors

H2a: Poor family dynamics will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2b: Poor peer relationships will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2c: Poor school functioning will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2d: Lower levels of neighborhood safety will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 
H2e: Heightened levels of perceived access to drugs and alcohol will be associated with increases in internalizing behaviors. 


Aim 3 (Exploratory): Explore unique SES and racial/ethnic group differences on the associations between multi-level ecological factors and poor mental health outcomes in adolescents.
registration_responses.q3: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q9:
The proposed data analysis will approach the currently available Baseline cross-sectional data (2.0.1) of this 10-year longitudinal dataset with a more holistic approach to understanding correlates and trends of development and wellbeing across a diverse group of US adolescents. This in efforts to promote research with an open-science framework. To ensure the blinding of patterns and summary statistics of variable of interest beyond demographic information, we will be utilizing the Data Exploration Analysis Portal (DEAP) which has taken measures to prevent post hoc hypothesis testing. Exploratory analysis will be conducted to investigate differences in mental health outcomes stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups. 

To my knowledge there have not been studies published yet looking at direct relations between screen time and internalizing behaviors using this dataset, alongside the interplay of multi-level ecological variables related to mental health outcomes in adolescence.
registration_responses.q11: The sample size for the baseline data of this adolescent cohort is 11,880. Parent/caregiver data is also collected, thus the sample size of adults in this study are 11,880 individuals at baseline data collection. This number is expected to decrease when accounting for missing data, which will be analyzed after pre-registration.
registration_responses.q12: This sample size was over sampled with the anticipated attrition rates (10%) in a 10-year longitudinal study of this magnitude. To capture the national diversity of the adolescent population in the U.S., a multi-stage probability sampling design of schools around each study site was conducted. There was an oversampling of African American and other races and relative under-sampling of Caucasian and Hispanics in order to achieve a more optimal racial/ethnic distribution in this cohort of adolescents (Garavan et al., 2018).
registration_responses.q22: We expect there may be differences in effect sizes across group of race/ethnicity and familial socioeconomic status. Therefore, as the exploratory aim, we will stratify by groups of race/ethnicity and familial SES and conduct bivariate correlates and multiple regression analyses to better understand potential unique associations between the multi-level ecological predictors and internalizing behavior outcomes.
registration_responses.q23:
**Note: This is a modification to the original submission of this pre-registration of this analysis (02-13-2020) due to measure variables that were not administered during the baseline measure that was after importing and data cleaning. Analysis had not been run prior to selecting an appropriate community-level measure.

registration_responses.q6.question:
This study draws from the Adolescent Brain and Cognitive Development (ABCD) Study, which has been designed as an open-access dataset through the NIMH Data Archive (NDA). The ABCD study is designed to be a multimodal longitudinal study uniquely capturing the development of adolescences through neuroimaging, biospecimen, neurocognition, mental and physical health measures, and equivalent parental self-reported measures across 10 years and 21 sites in the United States. Details of the adolescent sampling for recruitment can be found in prior publication (Garavan et al., 2018). 

For this particular analysis, I will be utilizing the self-reported measures of demographic information, psychological wellbeing, cognitive functioning, screen time, family dynamics, school functioning, neighborhood safety and community environment.
registration_responses.q10.question: Recruitment for this study is across 21 catchment areas in the mainland United States and data from children and parents are stored in the main data management site of University of California, San Diego. As a part of the open-access data initiative, the NIH has made the deidentified data publicly available for researchers globally. The data was obtained through data user agreement between NIH and UCI and an exempt data analysis protocol is in place for this specific study analysis, as there will be no direct interaction with the study participants and only data will be analyzed.

Predictors/Correlates: Screen Time; Cognitive Functioning (NIH Toolbox) Parental Monitoring Survey; Youth Family Environment Scale; Resiliency Survey (Peer Relationships); School Risk and Protective Factors; Brief Problem Monitoring; Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey; Community Drug Availability Measure

Covariates: Youth Demographics (age, gender, race/ethnicity); Parent Demographics (SES, highest education level, marital status)

(Please see attached document for details on each measure: JMHthesis_PreReg_VariableTable_UPDATE200410.docx)

registration_responses.q17.question:
Descriptive and frequency statistics will be initially conducted to understand the demographic and internalizing behavior (e.g. depressive and anxiety symptom) distributions of this study cohort. 

Bivariate correlations will be conducted to characterize the associations between multi-level ecological factors and internalizing behaviors. Effect sizes will be reported to compare the magnitude of the associations of potential predictors of internalizing behaviors. Multiple linear regression analysis will be performed to further investigate the associations between the ecological factors and internalizing behaviors above and beyond covariate demographic factors and relative to the factors of each ecological level to identify unique predictive factors of screen time. 

**Please see attached variable document for measure information
Outcome variables: internalizing behaviors (CBCL, KSADS) 
Predictor variables: Individual factors (Screen Time, Cognitive Functioning), family dynamics (Family Environment Survey, Parental monitoring Survey), peer relationships (Resilience Survey), school functioning (Brief Problem Monitoring – Teacher reported), neighborhood environment (Neighborhood Safety and Crime Survey), and community environment (Discrimination Survey). 
Covariates: child demographics (age, sex given at birth, race/ethnicity, pubertal development); parent demographics (family SES, highest parent education, marital status)

As an exploratory aim, run descriptives and bivariate correlations will be conducted stratified by socioeconomic and racial/ethnic groups. We will conduct similar multiple regression models stratified by SES and racial/ethnic groups, then test potential interaction effects.

attributes.title: Epistemic Cooperation
attributes.description:
Participants in this experiment play a collaborative quiz game with either a member of their political ingroup or a member of their political outgroup. We refer to this game as the Epistemic Game. Participants can therefore be apart of one of four possible dyads (a Republican paired with a Republican, a Republican paired with a Democrat, a Democrat paired with a Democrat, and a Democrat paired with a Republican).  We refer to these dyads as "pairing types." 

Other participants are sorted into a No-Quiz Control in which they interact with one another via a know-your-partner task, but do not play the epistemic game. We track both between- and within-subject outcome measures and compare these outcomes across pairing types and within pairing types across conditions.

attributes.title: WATERS project
attributes.description: The WATERS project will focus on a single, targeted goal: to build, deploy, and research a student-centered, universally accessible curriculum for learning water concepts and water career awareness in order to increase student interest in STEM careers by broadening the population of students who believe they have the ability and skills to pursue STEM careers.

and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation”

q4.value:
We hypothesize that the WATERs UDL (Universal Design for Learning) curriculum will increase students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, 21st century learning, and watershed content knowledge compared to the WATERs curriculum without UDL.  (note this is stating 5 hypotheses - one for each DV).

We hypothesize the effect of the WATERs UDL curriculum on students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, 21st century learning, and watershed content knowledge will be moderated by special needs and English Language Learning, such that those students with special needs and who are English Language Learners will have greater gains in the UDL condition than in the curriculum without UDL. (again note that this statement is summarizing 5 hypotheses - one for each of the 5 DVS)

We hypothesize the economic advantage of the school will not moderate the effect of the WATERs UDL curriculum on  students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, 21st century learning, and watershed content knowledge.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
30 teachers from 3 states will be randomly assigned to either the control or experimental group (7 teachers in each state will be assigned to the experimental group and 3 from each state will be assigned to the control group).

Teachers will be provided professional development (PD) on the project curriculum. The control groups’ curriculum implementation will include the same learning objectives and activities, but will not include the UDL technologies.

Students' aptitudes towards STEM and watershed content knowledge will be tested before and after the implementation of the WATERs curriculum. ANY MORE DETAIL HERE?

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Each of the 3 states has a “center director” who is a local education leader. The center director sends email blasts, shares flyers, etc with teachers in the state. Teachers volunteer to participate. Teacher also receive a $1200 stipend which is a motivator.
Universal Design for Learning (UDL) technology - The experimental group will consist of an UDL enhanced WATERs curriculum and the control group will consist of the WATERs curriculum without UDL.

Student level:
- Aptitudes towards STEM surveys (S-STEM) measured students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, and 21st century learning
- Watershed content knowledge (B-WET)
- Special needs (defined as having a 504 or IEP)
- English Language Learner status
- Expected grade
- Personal connection to adults with STEM careers
- Gender
- Race/ethnicity
- Age

School level:
- Socioeconomic status

- Students’ attitudes towards science will consist of the average of 9 items from the S-STEM
- Students’ attitudes towards engineering and technology will consist of the average of 9 items from the S-STEM
- Students’ attitudes towards  21st century learning will consist of the average of 11 items from the S-STEM
- Watershed content knowledge will consist of the number of correct questions on a 18 question test of watershed knowledge

The effectiveness of the UDL curriculum will be tested using Multi Level Modeling (MLM) with the lme4 package in R statistics. Students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, 21st century learning, and watershed content knowledge will be tested in separate models. These repeated measures (pretest and posttest) will be level 1predictors. Level 2 predictors will be student level characteristics (learning disability and ELL). Level 3 will be at the teacher level and will consist of the experimental condition (UDL or no UDL). 

The effectiveness of the UDL curriculum will be tested with the cross-level interaction between repeated measures at level 1 and experimental condition (UDL or no UDL) at level 3. Moderation by learning disability and ELL will be tested with a 3-way cross-level interaction between the repeated measures at level 1, the experimental condition at level 3, and these student level predictors at level 2.

q20.value: Data management will follow the guidelines of Tabachnick and Fidell (2007). Normality will be assessed by computing skewness and kurtosis. Linearity, and homoscedasticity will be assessed by checking distributions and plots. If needed transformations will follow Tabachnick and Fidell’s (2007) recommendations in Table 4.3.

q22.value:
Outliers will be excluded using the guidelines of Tabachnick and Fidell (2007). Univariate outliers will be tested by standardizing continuous variables. Cases with standardized scores above 3.29 will be considered potential univariate outliers. Multivariate outliers will be identified using the Mahalanobis distance, which is evaluated as 𝜒2 with degrees of freedom equal to the number of variables.   

All outliers will be described. After determining that an outlier is part of the intended sample, data transformations will be considered based on the criteria of Tabachnick and Fidell (2007) - Table 4.3. If transformation are deemed unacceptable, we will next consider changing the score(s) on the variable(s) for the outlaying case(s). Kline (2011) suggests replacing extreme scores with the most extreme score that is within three standard deviations from the mean.

q23.value: We will use FIML to account for missing data.

q24.value:
We will explore whether students gender, race/ethnicity, and students' expected grades moderate the effect of the UDL WATERs curriculum on students’ attitudes towards math, science, engineering and technology, 21st century learning, and watershed content knowledge.
 
We will explore whether STEM related career interest change after the WATERs curriculum.
